newsitem.title: UK: IPE Brent firms on Iraq, Nigeria, technicals.
newsitem.headline: IPE Brent firms on Iraq, Nigeria, technicals.

text.p: IPE Brent crude oil futures stabilised at higher levels after a combination of technical buying and fundamental news from Iraq and Nigeria pushed numbers up in the morning session, traders said.
June Brent was 22 cents a barrel firmer at 1157 GMT and stood at $18.56 while May gas oil was $1.25 firmer at $166.50 a tonne.
"The news from Nigeria and Iraq has not really had an awful lot of effect," one IPE dealer said.
Iraq's official news agency INA said on Tuesday a number of helicopters was sent to the border area to pick up pilgrims. The U.S. said on Monday it would "respond appropriately" to any such flights.

"The Iraqi story took it up to a bit of a peak," a broker said. "But it seems to be just a bit of sabre rattling on the part of Iraq and the U.S. It is unlikely they are going to blow pilgrims out of the sky."

Some traders in the physical markets were offhand about Shell Nigeria's declaration of force majeure on Nigeria's 450-475,000 barrels per day (bpd) exports of Bonny crude oil with effect from Monday because of a strike by contractors at the tanker terminal.
"This kind of thing (the strike) is normal, very normal," one said, but added that the declaration of force majeure was unusual.
A broker at the IPE echoed the sentiment. "The comment about it being 'very normal' summed that situation up very well," he said.
Technical analysts said they saw resistance firstly at $18.62 a barrel, the bottom of a chart gap from earlier in the month, then at $18.77, the top of the same chart gap.
Dealers were also aware that U.S. markets could later exert a strong influence in London, given that the May NYMEX crude oil futures contract expires on Tuesday.
